text:
These were SO GOOD!!!  I don't normally  make Mexican food, but these were so delicious.  I did follow some other reviewers suggestions.  I left out the water, but kept the other ingredients the same.  Only other differences from the original recipe were that I poached my chicken and shredded it.  I used light sour cream and reduced fat cheddar cheese to save some extra calories.  I will use this as my go to enchilada recipe from now on.  I love that you don't have to fry the tortillas before rolling them, it really cuts out a lot of fat in that is normally in the traditional enchilada recipes.  Thanks for sharing a great recipe!!!

READ REVIEWS to tailor to your taste.  This is an excellent recipe without too many changes.  The only thing I changed was omitted the 1/2 cup water (not needed and takes away from the flavour) and added cut black olives to the top.  I used "La Victoria" brand taco sauce which tastes authentic and is a bit thicker than other brands and corn tortillas which were absolutely key to the taste.  (If they crack and break as you are assembling just go with it, it comes out as a lovely lasagna type dish)  Thank you for the recipe

text:
These were addicting. First off, I used leftover grilled chicken and shredded it with a fork. I left out the tomato sauce + water but kept everything else in the mix. I did add canned green chiles and a little bit of enchilada sauce to the mix. I also threw in some red pepper and tabasco, as I found it kind of bland. After rolling the enchiladas, I skipped the salsa and used the rest of the enchilada sauce and cheese on top. As you can notice I didn't really measure any of the my changes. I just sort of winged it.

strib5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3057.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this recipe!  This is probably one of our favorite recipes.  I have used it over and over again the last couple of years.  I did make a few changes to it.  I added a little of red cayeene pepper to the meat/sauce mix for an extra kick and some extra cheese. One other thing that I have done if your not too concerned about the added calories is you can fry the flour tortillas in crisco just before stuffing them. The trick is not to fry them for too long, just long enough for the tortilla to begin bubbling. You whisk them out of the pan when you see the air pockets beginning to brown and expand with a pair of metal thongs and pretty much start stuffing and rolling them when they are hot.  You can let them cool a little if needed. Very tasty with a nice crispy texture and they also hold their shape better. Follow the remaining directions of the recipe as it states and then serve. Yummy!!  Usually we have extra meat/sauce mixture left I just pour it over the tortiallas like a sauce and cover with cheese.  This variation isn't of course for light weights who are worried about calories and fat, but it's well worth the extra effort. Try using hamburger too for another flavor adventure.

text:
This is a great recipe for ideas.  I used the base idea and just changed a few things based on the reviews.  I sauteed the onion and garlic, then I added the chicken with enough Enchilada sauce to moisten everything.  Added the spices and simmered for 20 minutes.  Then I added the cheese and cooled for a bit added the sour cream and then rolled in tortillas.  Added that to a dish with a bit of enchilada sauce on the bottom.  Also, after all were rolled I put the rest of the enchilada sauce on the top with cheese on top of that and that was it.  Did not use taco sauce or water.  Great dish.  Have made it twice and it is a big hit.  Served with Spanish rice and refried beans.  Enchiladas were topped with lettuce, sour cream and salsa.  Yummy!!!

text:
these are REALLY good!  i have made them just as the recipe says to and i've also made them using enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce.  i must say that i enjoyed them better as written with one exception.  the taste in this recipe is a little sweeter than enchilada sauce, but i have found that substituting salsa for tomato sauce gives a nice balance.  (when i use the tomato sauce AND the taco sauce together i feel that it's really a good flavor but i get sick of it kinda quick)next time i am going to put in some green chiles.  have fun with it and i would honestly say you don't need the water.  i like mine thick!

I took the advice of some reviewers and left out the water and also cut back on the tomato sauce. text:
These were definitely 5-star enchiladas, though I admit I have no real experience with authentic Mexican food, only what you find in restaurants on the East Coast. Anyway, I forgot to buy tomato sauce, so I put a can of tomatoes in the blender. I also put in a jar of salsa, and the type of salsa you use is really going to change it. Mine was corn and black bean salsa, so it went well - the corn especially. The tortillas I used were too big, so I made them size XL from also adding more chopped pepper. I used homemade enchilada sauce and they were so fantastic. Awesome as leftovers too!

text:
My whole family is sitting here stuffed to the max after eating this recipe with a few modifications - I did as other said and cut the tomato sauce and water in half. Also, they had a sale on chicken thighs at my local super market so I needed a way to use em' up so I boiled them in some water (added 1 chopped onion, S&P, 1/8 of crushed red pepper and 1T hot sauce to the water). Gently boiled it till the meat came easily off the bone about 20min or so. Drained,then shredded it. I followed the recipe pretty much the rest of the way with the exception of the green chilies substitution(instead of green peppers) and a dash of cayenne pepper. Topped with enchilada sauce and cheddar cheese YUM!

userID:
1655346
Display Name:
22032
isPro:
False

8

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was much better than I thought it would be; thanks to the positive reviews that I even tried this, and thanks to the suggestions for making it even better, while still using what I had on hand. I (a) poached the chicken in broth for about 12 minutes, and shredded it with 2 forks; (b) sauteed onions & garlic on low, then added 1 jar of salsa and cooked down a bit. (I didn't have any green peppers or canned diced chiles.)   Added some cumin, but that's it. Took about half the sauce and put it in a separate bowl & pureed it. (Didn't have any other enchilada sauce or taco sauce.) To the remaining sauce in the pan, I added the shredded chicken, sour cream, and cheddar cheese. Spread some of the pureed sauce in the bottom of the baking dish, wrapped the chicken mixture in whole-wheat flour tortillas, put them in the dish, topped with remaining sauce and cheese. Result was good, not very saucy, which worked well for my kids.  My picky ones ate it and that makes me happy. This was my first time making enchiladas, though I cook quite a bit, and I was pleasantly surprised. Thank you!

My husband and I loved this recipe!! I took the advice from other members and made a few changes. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The filling was fantastic.  I put them together the night before and threw them in the oven when I got home from work that night after pouring taco sauce and cheese on them.  Pretty quick and tasty.  I imagine they would be even better if they hadn't sat all night in my fridge!  Next time I'll assemble them right before I stick them in the oven.  I made some changes (doesn't everyone?).  I poached the chicken in chicken broth and threw in the peppers and onions towards the end.  I drained out the liquid (except for 1 cup of the broth) and shredded the chicken.  I cooked the rest according to the recipe, only instead of adding water I added the chicken broth from poaching the chicken a little at a time until I got a consistency I liked.  My only complaint: not spicy enough!  My family and I love spicy food so while the flavor was good, it was lacking that extra oomph to be mexican!  Next time I'll add some red pepper flakes.

This dish has got great flavor but I made a few changes of my own.  I omitted the water and tomato sauce but added a can of diced tomatos with green chilies.  I also added black olives and used fresh cilantro.  The mix was still a little soup like so I alowed it to cook down for about 35 to 40 min before filling. text:
This was a great recipe! One thing that I will definitely change is the garlic--I just did not like garlic in my enchiladas. Otherwise, it tasted fantastic. I chopped/shredded my chicken into smaller pieces that cubed, added black beans (which were delicious!) and used enchilada sauce instead of taco. I really recommend not adding the enchilada sauce and cheese on top at the beginning of baking. Instead, take it out like 5-10 minutes before hand and then put the toppings on. They got too baked for me. Otherwise, superb!

text:
"I know many if you have found this recipe to produce a soupy mess if the water isn't cooked down. Please try my variation on the recipe: Omit: 1 (15 ounce) can tomato sauce 1/2 cup water 1 (12 ounce) jar taco sauce 1 tablespoon chili powder 1/2 pint sour cream Replace the ingredients above with the following: 1 can (10 oz) La Preferida Enchilada Sauce (Hot or Mild) 1 jar (16 oz) Frontera Grill Salsa (I like the Chipotle Salsa)"

I love your changes to this recipe, it cuts down on prep time, all you have to do is pour and stir! I kept the sour cream in the mixture b/c I love sour cream :). You should submit it as a separate recipe, I always come back to this page but only to refresh my memory on your variation!
Thanks!!

Hubby and I thought these were really good. I made them using homemade tortillas (Tortillas I) so these were nice and hearty. I didn't read many of the reviews before beginning (I know, I know...) so I missed out on the part about the sauce being too runny. Next time I will just omit the 1/2 cup of water and add an extra chicken breast. It was still delicious, I mean you have to eat enchiladas with a fork anyway, right? I unexpectedly ran out of onions so I added 2 tsp. of oinion powder to the sour cream part of the sauce, and I added 1 tsp. of hot chili sauce and an extra clove of garlic to the tomato sauce, nothing major. This will be our enchilada recipe from now on!

text:
I feel it would be unfair to give this recipe only 4 stars, as it gave me the basics to create my own super dish (with help from reviews). I replaced the salsa with pico de gallo. I actually boiled the chicken with some lime, salt and pepper until it was almost fully cooked - thought it would be more tender that way. I then cubed the chicken. I used a Mexican four cheese combo. Also, I used a homemade green salsa that a friend had given me for the holidays. Also, I just layered tortillas on the bottom of the dish, put the filling on top, put tortillas on top, then the "enchilada" sauce and cheese. Enchilada pie! Easy and yummy! (oh, I replaced the green bell pepper with jalopenos - from a jar, and I only used 2 large chicken breasts and put it in a 9x11 dish.)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first cut the chicken into strips and sauteed with 3 cloves of garlic, salt and pepper and then cut into cubes. I then sauteed the onions with a bit of olive oil before mixing everything else in. I took the advice of other reviewers and took out the tomato sauce, water and sour cream and substituted the Old El Paso chunky salsa in medium. I only mixed about 2/3 cup of salsa into the chicken mixture and just poured the rest overtop of the rolled enchiladas before putting in the oven to avoid the sogginess problem. I also added chopped red peppers and mushrooms into the mix and used a little bit more cheese to bring it all together.  Instead of taco sauce, I used enchilada sauce which I poured overtop the salsa. Overall, quite good.

text:
My sister and I cooked this for my family and it was excellent!!  Some of my family members don't like it real spicy so we cut out the onions and peppers.  We also used a little bit of Monterey Jack cheese with white cheddar.  I highly recommend shredding the chicken with a fork and then your fingers once you can handle it; it makes for a phenomenal texture change!  My whole family absolutely loved them!  And once it cooks, as long as you let it sit for 10 minutes before serving, they're not nearly as messy.

text:
This recipe was really delicious and super easy to fix!  I took the advice of some of the reviewers and omitted the water...GOOD CALL!  If the water had been in there, it would have definitely been too soupy.  I also substituted enchilada sauce for taco sauce as well as used about half the tomato sauce called for in the recipe.  The only other change I made was that I cubed the chicken first and then sauteed it with the onions until it was no longer pink and then followed the rest of the recipe from there.

WE definitely will be making this again!!

text:
Umm...okay well I omitted the water, used only 8 oz sour cream, used lemon pepper because I was out of black pepper,  used one 4 oz can of diced green chili instead of bell pepper, subbed mexican 4 cheese, and the real problem came in when I tried to substitute enchilada sauce for taco sauce.  Oh My God.  Enchilada sauce is so strong!  It was too strong for my taste buds so I used one 16 ounce can of mild salsa mixed with 1 8 ounce can tomato sauce...which turned out far too sweet, so I poured in about 1/2 cup enchilada sauce and it turned out just right.  Gah.  Next time I will try to stick to the original recipe!

If you like Mexican food, it definitely satisfies!  Try making Sweet Corn Cake as a side dish.

text:
My family and I love Mexican food and I have to say this was the best enchilada dish we have ever eaten. The only changes I made were leaving out the water and oregano. I used enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce and I also added some cilantro and cumin. I boiled the chicken with 2 cloves of garlic, onion powder, parsley and chili powder. I sauteed the onion and green pepper first, before adding the rest of the ingredients. What a fantastic dish!!!! Thanks so much for sharing your recipe with us Debbie. It was a big hit.

I have to admit I was a little sceptical seeing all the sour cream in this recipe.

I tried it and I didn't modify a thing.  The recipe was fantastic! - the family loved these.  I did traditional beef enchiladas on the same night, as back-up, and these chicken ones were gobbled up way faster!  I did use lots of marble cheddar cheese on top.  I had filling left over which I kept in the fridge.  My wife stuffed a couple of tortillas with it each day and put the 'burritos' in a container to heat up in the microwave for lunch at work.

Was very tasty.  Only made a few modifications (based on personal preferences) - I grilled the chicked and then shredded it and I also sauteed the onions, green pepper and garlic before I put the chicken back in the skillet.  Hubby liked it.  I suspect this dish will be even better tomorrow.
Also - I did omit the water as others suggested.  Not sure why the water is necessary - it came out great without it.

text:
I thought this recipe would be a good way to use up some pulled pork from a roast that had been in the freezer a little too long. It turned out really well, in spite of some unforseen substitutions. I planned to substitute the pulled pork for the chicken. Then I realized the can on the pantry shelf said tomato PASTE, not sauce, so I added a little water to the paste and used it. Then I discovered the container of sour cream had grown hair prettier than my own so I substituted plain yogurt. (Sour cream would have been better, but this worked in a pinch.)I also used the blended Mexican cheeses ...just because.
In spite of it all, this recipe definitely goes in the "yum" file!

Awesome!  I boiled and shredded the chicken the night before.  I also added a bit of cumin and garlic powder to the inner mix.  First topped with rolled enchiladas with cheese (so it wouldn't "float") and then smothered them with Trader Joe's Enchilada sauce instead of "taco sauce." text:
Didn't have any chicken so I made cheese enchiladas instead.  I cooked the onions, garlic, and green pepper in a little olive oil and then mixed in the sour cream, shredded cheese and only a small amount of the tomato sauce.  I had to make the whole dish like a casserole because the mixture was little too runny, with no chicken,  to roll up into tortillas.  I layered the tortillas and cheese mixure and topped it all off with the taco sauce and more cheese.  It was so yummy, but I can't wait to try it again with some chicken.
Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe, probably because it wasn't a traditional enchilada recipe, which I'm not at all fond of. This looked like enchilada's but didn't have the flavor of enchilada's. Next time, though, I will saute the onions first so that they are not crunchy (my kids wouldn't eat this because of the onions). I also took other's suggestions and stirred in 1/2 of the tomato sauce mixture and then used the rest for the cover instead of taco sauce (I didn't have any). I used Boiled Chicken (submitted by George)instead of the chicken breasts. If you're a traditional enchilada lover, you most likely will not enjoy this recipe. Read other's reviews.

text:
Wonderful!  I don't like things all that spicy, so I used 1/4 tsp. pepper and 1 tsp. chili powder (perfect!).  I also used only 1 - 8 oz. can tomato sauce, and was so glad I didn't use more.  I also sauteed the onions and bell pepper before adding them, and would definitely do that again (the baking time wouldn't have been enough to make them very tender).  I had enough mixture for 10 tortillas.  Instead of taco sauce, I used "Red Enchilada Sauce," also from this site (awesome!!).  I think next time I'll double the enchilada sauce though.  Thanks so much for the recipe!

I used the "Red Enchilada Sauce" recipe from this site in place of both the tomato and taco sauce and would highly recommend it, great flavour, zingy but not too hot.  I would have given this recipe a 5 because both my husband and son loved the dish, but my daughter and I didn't like how the tortilla wraps got really soggy/doughy kind of tasted mushy in the mouth.  Nobody else has mentioned this in their reviews so I think it is supposed to turn out like this.  The filling is fantastic and the sauce to cover was great maybe next time I will use it over rice or spoon it into crisp taco shells.

Display Name:
ACOTERILLO

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is is an excellent recipe!  Tastes even better the second day as leftovers.  I made a few changes though that I would like to share. With these changes the prep time is a bit longer:

I added 1/2 bunch green onions chopped; used 1 and 1/2 tbsp chili powder (I'm from Texas and we like it hot!); 1 and 1/2 clove garlic chopped; 1 cup shredded sharp cheddar and 1 cup shredded taco cheeses in the mixture.  Then I used 1 cup shredded cheeses at the end as topping.  Once it came out of the oven, I added 1/2 cup chopped  onion to the top.  Instead of 1/2 cup water, I used 1/2 can RO-TEL green peppers and chilis (including all of the juices).  Also, instead of 1/2 pint (8 oz) sour cream, I used 4 oz sour cream and 4 oz cream cheese.  I think this really added to the richness and flavor of  the recipe.  ENJOY!!
acoterillo

text:
This was really, really awesome!!

I did modify it a bit:

-  I used corn tortillas.  Flour tortillas are a sin.  Make sure to follow the instructions on the back of the bag - if you dont, they crumble...

-  I used shredded chicken instead (boil for 15 minues then pick apart /w fork)

-  Didn't use either spice, but put a ton of fresh cilantro in instead.

-  Got the "Monterey Jack/Cheddar" cheese mix instead of plain cheddar

-  When it was cooked, I topped with diced tomatoes & cilantro.  Next time I'll add some lime juice to make more of a salsa topping.

Make sure to serve this with a good mexican beer like Dos Equis.

text:
I give this 5 stars because the unenjoyable part of the recipe was on my end--- my taco sauce choice (Pace's Classic Taco Sauce) didn't mesh well with the rest of it, so the filling was definitely the best part. I agree that the water can probably be left out. I used fat-free sour cream. I didn't have cheddar or green pepper, so I used mozzerella and orange pepper, and it was tasty. I didn't use as much cheese as the recipe called for to make it less dairy-intensive. I had trouble rolling the tortillas, as I only had small ones on hand, so I ended making a layered dish that my husband termed "Echilsana."

text:
This came out awesome, though I made a few minor (or not so minor?) changes...
I used a rotisserie chicken and just pulled it apart, used a can of mild green chiles instead of the green pepper, used corn tortillas instead of flour, and used salsa instead of the taco sauce on top of the whole thing.  Here's the biggie... my corn tortillas weren't rolling even after I softened them, so I ended up making it into a casserole-- layered tortillas, chicken mixture, tortillas, chicken mix, tortillas, salsa, then cheese... served with sour cream on the side.  It came out unbelieveable, and was so much easier than rolling the darn enchiladas individually!!!

text:
Fantastic recipe. I do make a few changes. I use  a can of chopped green chilis instead of bellpepper and red enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce and no water. I also shred my chicken instead of cubing it. I use 8oz of tomato sauce and no onion. The reason for no using onion is the fact that i serve fresh salsa with the enchilada, I use the Fresh California Salsa off this site. I also use homemade flour tortillas, there is a recipe on this for that as well. It does add about 45 minutes to the cooking time but it tastes even better using homemade tortillas. And i usually add 2 or 3 more chicken breasts and really overstuff the tortillas.  This is my boyfriends favorite dish. It is definitely near the top of the list on my favorites too.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Of all the chicken enchilada recipes I've made from this site, this one is my husband's favorite. I modified it a little after reading reviews and turned it into the perfect recipe for my family's tastes. I shred my chicken rather than cubing it. To avoid a watery mess, I only use an 8oz can of tomato sauce and omit the water completely. I use half a tablespoon of hot chili powder and substitute the green pepper with a can of chopped green chiles. Then I substitute the taco sauce with a can of red enchilada sauce. Yummy!! Be sure to grease the pan first and/or sperad some of the enchilada sauce over the bottom and sprinkle more cheese over the top before baking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These enchiladas are awesome!!  I followed the recipe for the most part although I only used half of the tomato sauce and I left out the water.  I used mexian shredded cheese instead of cheddar.  I topped them with enchilada sauce AND taco sauce. I also added a can of sliced olives.  Actually now that I think about it, I altered quite a bit of the recipe but the jist is still there.  After cutting up the chicken, I left it out of the pan and I lightly sauteed the onions, green peppers, garlic, olives, and added about 2 tablespoons of canned green chilies.  I let these cool while I combined the cheese, sour cream, parsley, oregano, pepper, salt, tomato sauce (1/2 the can), chili powder (used mexican style)in a large mixing bowl and then mixed it all together.  This prevented the cheese from melting to begin with and gave the mixture a better consistency to work with. Try it my way!

Very tasty, easy to make recipe. I did not use water and I only used an 8 ounce can of tomato sauce. I think it would be like soup if you used the ingredients as called for. I also used diced green chilies instead of green pepper, and enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce. My family loves this recipe. We make it about twice a month.

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe after reading the other reviews.  I omitted the water all together.  I used two fresh plum tomatoes instead of canned and used mexican cheese instead of cheddar for the filling.  I also added green chillies, sliced olives and 1/2 tsp. cumin to the final mix.  For the topping I used a third of salsa, a third of enchilada sauce and a third of medium chipolte sauce for a kick.  I also used more the a 3/4 cup of cheese on top.  It was excellent.  I thought it was easy to make though I cook alot.

text:
My kids loved these and my neighbor stopped in and ate one and took two home. I made subtle changes based on other‚Äôs reviews.
I used half a block of Philly cream cheese instead of sour cream.
I used enchilada sauce and tostitos jar of salsa instead of water, tomato sauce , and red chili powder.
I used red onions finely chopped.
I used green bell pepper and a small 4 oz can of mild green Chile‚Äôs. All the products I used were mild.
I used a few shakes of cumin powder. I used the other ingredients listed except where I told you I substituted.
My kids said the mix of sweet and spicy was just right.
There was a huge pan to save and freeze some for another day or use in a different way. I put some of the enchilada mix on small street taco corn tortillas and it was a perfect little portion for me!

I have made this twice. It's the only enchilada I have ever made. The taste is great, but both times the onions needed to be cooked more. I would suggest cooking the onions for 3-4 minutes by itself before you mix in the cheese and what not. It still technically works...I don't mind the onions have cooked, but my husband wasn't a fan because of the onions not being done. He ate it anyway though...
Save time by replacing the chicken with Rotisserie chicken already done. :)

Ingrid

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I needed to doctor these up a little bit, otherwise I would have given 5 stars. 
I think this is a great base recipe to start if you're not sure what flavors your family will like. 
My family LOVES these with my slight alterations. Even when I make a bigger batch I hardly have any leftovers. The leftovers never make it longer than a day! 

Here's what I changed about this recipe. 
1) I  boil the chicken in chicken broth instead of frying it. 
2) I shred the chicken instead of cubing it then return Chicken to pan
3) Omit Sour cream. Keep the cheese, onion, oregano, parsley, and pepper. 
4) Swap out tomato sauce for red enchilada sauce. 
5) Omit the water. I guess you could add a little in if the mixture is too dry, but instead I would add more red enchilada sauce. Keep Chili Powder, salt, Green pepper, and garlic. 
6) Swap out "taco sauce" for red enchilada sauce. Top with more cheese than what is probably recommended in a single serving.

This one is bizarre. As the top favorable reviewer says, the recipe produces a sloppy mess, so what all the enthusiasts do is rewrite the recipe to suit themselves, and praise the result to the sky.  Meanwhile, I'm left with a sloppy mess. Is it any good? I don't know .  Maybe, maybe not, but the only thing I can think of to do with what I've got is cook up some rice, and serve the mess over it.  My advice to newbies like me: read the reviews, and choose your variation.

text:
My husband and I loved this recipe!! I did do some modifying.  First, I used some red and yellow ‚Äúmini peppers‚Äù I had on hand.  I used white onions. While I was saut√©ing the chicken that I lightly salted with adobo seasoning, I cut it up while it was saut√©ing, to bypass the next step and ensure the chicken no longer had ‚Äúpink‚Äù in it.  Then I saut√©ed the chicken with the onions, peppers and garlic before adding the tomato sauce and other spices, forgoing any salt since I used the adobo seasoning, and ingredients.  I don‚Äôt think any water was necessary and I used La Preferida hot red chili enchilada sauce to top off my casserole.  WAY tasty!!  A little dollop of sour cream and a sprig of cilantro on top,  made this not only a tasty dinner, but visually attractive as well!! Enjoy!!

text:
I made this for my grandchildren and it was truly a huge hit. I did only give this 4 stars because I had to adjust the recipe.
I read all the reviews and their biggest complaints were too watery and not enough flavor! 
So I omitted the water and used a can of creme of chicken soup and a can of black beans (rinsed and drained). I also doubled the chili powder. I made a double batch(16) enchiladas ,my 2 grandchildren and their father ate all and the next day was asking me to please make some more. This time I made 21 (thinking I would have some for the freezer)  nope they finished those off in 2 days. Now my son in law wants me to make 150 so he can take them to work..  He said he bragged on them at work and everybody wants to try them too.

text:
So I read a lot of reviews before making this recipe. I took their advice and substituted the tomato sauce for tomato paste. I also left out the water. Instead I took the empty tomato paste can and filled half of it with water and stirred with the contents left over in the can and used that. The chicken was boiled in chicken stock instead of regular water. and I browned up the onion and garlic before adding the cooked chicken and seasoning. I also took some taco sauce and put it on the bottom of the pan before placing the enchiladas in it to bake. I made a vegetarian version of this at the same time but cut the recipe in half since I'm the only vegetarian at home. Both versions came out amazing! I will definitely make this again!

userID:
12518006
Display Name:
lori

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This needs help, do not let the rating suck you in. I don't understand why you would cook the chicken and then cube. Here are the changes I made: seasoned the chicken with taco seasoning, cubed and then browned in a skillet. Once browned, add diced onion and garlic. Add green chiles and some chipotle chiles in Adobo sauce for flavor (only if you like some spice). Add 16 oz of sour cream (who says 1 pint?!?), add 1 cup of sharp chedder cheese, add 1 jar of salsa or enchilada sauce. Season with salt, pepper and garlic salt. I am not big into measuring spices, I go by flavor so season to your taste buds. Before assembling the enchiladas using CORN TORTILLAS, cover the bottom of a 9x13 with enchilada sauce or taco sauce. Fill your tortillas, be sure that the rolled tortillas are covered with enchilada sauce or you will have dried up and crusty tortillas. Sprinkle with cheddar cheese and bake to warm through and melt the cheese (remember, the chicken is cooked through already).

country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  I followed suggestions of others and did the following: Cube chicken first, then cook and drain. Set chicken aside. Add onion, green peppers to pan. Saut√© 2 mins. Add 2 cloves garlic for 1 min. Add rest of ingredients but substitute salsa for tomato sauce and enchilada sauce for taco sauce and add 1 small can of green chiles and 2 teaspoons of ground cumin and 2 tablespoons fresh cilantro.  Return chicken to pan. After rolling tortillas, add additional fresh cilantro when coating with enchilada sauce and cheddar. After baking for 20 minutes, put under broiler until cheese just slightly chars. Don't let it burn!

text:
I made this for the first time, and made 36 enchiladas.  I read the other reviews and added green chilles, instead of bell pepper. I'm currently in Germany, so finding good enchilada sauce is rather hard. I used a combination of taco sauce and salsa sauce, though it can't be that authentic. 

I boiled the chicken for about 15 minutes in chicken broth, with tomato sauce, pepper, cayenne pepper, garlic cloves, and salt. Then I shredded it with forks. 

I lightly fried the onions and green chilies together. 

Added cream cheese to the mix to make it more creamy. 

In the end, I didn't have enough sauce to pour over top and that was kind of sad. 

But everyone loved them and thought they were good, not authentic mexican food, but better than the "mexican" food in Germany!

text:
Only because of time, and my desire to spend as little effort as possible, and because I couldn't find the excellent recipe that I used before, here is what I did‚Ä¶ I combined about three different recipes for the taste desired, and it turned out perfectly. Oh, and I also used the Mission Carb Balance tortillas, cutting over 20 g of carbs. Doesn't taste any different.For 2 pounds of chicken, either cube them or cut them into small strips. Saut√© in olive oil till no longer pink, add one small diced or sliced onion, 1 teaspoon cumin, two clothes of garlic, one and a half teaspoons oregano, 8 ounces sour cream, salt and pepper to taste, and shredded sharp cheese as desired. I also added some diced fresh tomatoes. You could add black beans or olives or anything you would like to make the tortilla more full. The cheese is not necessary if you add the sour cream.For about a third of the green chili enchiladas sauce in the bottom of a baking pan, 11 x 14 is recommended if you are using the large tortilla shells. This will make eight enchiladas or tortillas. Place them seam-down in the pan, for the rest of the green chili sauce on top, and sprinkle cheese from and to and on top of each one, just enough to cover.Bake uncovered at 350¬∞ for about 20 minutes.,

text:
my family loves this recipe!  delicious!  made it 2x in the last month-- I followed the recs of others and used 1 jar enchilada sauce/ and 1 jar salsa instead of tomato sauce and H2O, not watery at all !   I also used diced red bell pepper instead of green and added chilli powder and cayenne pepper to the mild sauces (to control the spice level).  layered the chicken/ diced scallions/ bell peppers and cheese in the tortillas, rolled them up/ poured sauce overall and topped w/ lots more cheese.  Perfect!  use shredded rotissiere chicken if short on time-- also can make ahead, refrigerate, and bake an extra 5-10 mins or so.  could also top cheese w/ chopped cilantro before baking but we didn't have any on hand.

text:
This was very good.  It is very unusual for me to change a recipe when I make it the first time, unless the reviews have changes that seem to make sense.  Many of the changes seemed to make sense, so I did add and delete some of the ingredients.  I did not use any water or tomato sauce at all.  I added chili peppers and left out the green pepper.  With the chili peppers and the sour cream, the mixture was soupy enough (I can't imagine how soupy it would be with the tomato sauce and water-wow!).  I also left out the chili powder and used taco seasoning instead.  I used the rest of the ingredients called for in the recipe and used that heated mixture as the filling of the tortillas (although corn tortillas are more authentic, I don't like corn tortillas).  And then I topped the tortillas with a can of enchilada sauce with Cheddar cheese on top of that.  Delish!!! My kids had seconds!! :)

text:
I would reduce the tomato sauce to 12 oz (3/4) can because the final chicken/sauce mixture was too wet.   When assembling the tortillas, sauce leaked out heavily as I was placing them in the pan. I simmered the mixture about 15 minutes before preparing the tortillas to thicken it up.  Alternately you could start with 3/4 can of tomato sauce and add a little at a time

This was really good! Time consuming, but the end result was worth it.  I only used two chicken breasts for this recipe and we ended up W/ six enchiladas! Was not a fan at all. I have spent my entire life in the city where Frozen Margaritas were invented, so we know Tex-Mex. I followed the recipe to a 'T' and was not very happy with it. 1) enchiladas should always be on corn IMO. 2) You should never put tomato sauce in the enchiladas. 3) The texture was more like a smothered burrito and less like an enchilada. With that being said the flavor wasn't bad, it just wasn't what I want from enchiladas.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
my family loves this, recipe!! I do make changes  but they are mostly because I know what my family likes.  I have done this with poached chicken and also with fajita seasoned frozen chicken breast from Foster Farms ( I get this at Marianos),  I dont add green pepper or chilies, I do add roasted corn .  I don't measure the sour cream I just add it by table sppons to get the creamy texture I like and I use Fontera Grill salsa.  I also don't measure out the cheese just add it as I go.  I saute the chicken and chopped onion with garlic then add the sour cream, salt and pepper to taste, salsa and cheese.  I also have added smoked chipotle chili powder  and keep tasting then I might add garlic powder, onion powder, cumin, and more salt and pepper if needed.  I also use enchilada sauce and cheese on top.  Thank you so much for the recipe, I love recipes that inspire me to be creative!

super easy recipe. I love this recipe!  My stand by for an easy, nutritious meal.   I tossed 4 breast into my slow cooker with a can of Rotel. userID:
21288241
Display Name:
ginakitchen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
33
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cooked the chicken in one cup of water , 1 teas powdered chicken bouillon, table chili powder and 1 teas cumin.  Cubed chicken and continued cooking down the liquid. When the liquid cooked down, I Removed the chicken and added onion to the pan to soften, 4 oz can of mild chilis ( instead of green pepper) & added garlic. Also added a can of drained black beans. Cooked all together then added the chicken, spices as listed in the recipe, a cup of sour cream, a cup of Mexican cheese and 8 oz jar of taco sauce. Wrap in flour tortillas and place in baking dish. Top with a mixture of 10 oz can of enchilada sauce mixed with 1/4 cup of half-and-half. Top with Mexican and cheddar cheese and bake.   Really nice served with rice, lettuce and chopped tomato, chopped scallions and sour cream or guacamole.

text:
Do not add the water and tomato sauce! Reviewers who have given this high marks have substituted for these items. As written this recipe is soupy and Italian-flavored as many have stated. To make it a 5-star recipe, you need to substitute items, which means THIS recipe is NOT a 5-star. Follow other suggestions and use Mexican salsa and enchilada sauce in place of the water, tomato sauce and taco sauce. Add green chilis to chicken mixture and use corn tortillas. NOW you have a 5-star recipe!

text:
I wanted to rate this 3.5 stars. The flavor was phenomenal, but I really wish I had read the reviews first. The sauce was extremely watery and I ended up straining some out and dipped the two extra tortillas I had in it as a snack. Next time I plan on omitting the water and using an 8oz can of tomato sauce instead. I'd also like to try it with Mexican 4 cheese with green chiles instead of green pepper, topped with enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce. I also used chicken thighs, because my husband is picky and hates white meat. I am hoping for a 5 star rating after I make the above changes, because this recipe definitely has potential! Also, it definitely was not what I would call a quick meal, but not so bad considering it easily feeds 4-5 people!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The sauce is way to thin to just put in the tortillas.  I put refried beans on the shell then used a slotted spoon to drain off the liquid and spooned a healthy serving of the chicken mix on top of he bean... topped that with some of the shredded cheddar.. a few tablespoons of the sauce from the pan and folded them closed.  Poured some of the sauce over each enchilada and topped them with more cheddar and baked and cooled like the recipe calls for.   They were delicious.. ended up with extra sauce.. I normally freeze it but it wasn't enough to make more than one or two and wasn't sure with the sour cream how it would thaw so I discarded it.  Gave it 4 stars because it had to be modified due to the sauce being too thin but the flavor was very good.

text:
I made this a few nights ago, and it was amazing. Everyone that tried it loved it, they said it was better then ones they had in restaurants. I did make some changes after reading some of the comments. First, I didn't add any water. Second, I replaced tomato sauce with 10 Ounce jar of salsa, and replaced taco sauce with a 16 Ounce jar of enchilada sauce. I cooked the chicken in the crockpot for about 4 hours on high with chicken broth, salt, and pepper. Then shredded the chicken with two forks. I also added Cayenne pepper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good foundation, needed some "flare".  Followed the advice of other reviewers: 
I poached the chicken in chicken broth with some oregano; sea salt and a packet if Sazon seasoning, then shredded with a fork and set aside. 
I sauted the onions in a bit of olive oil before adding fresh parsley and the remaining ingredients in the recipe. I also used  mild salsa instead of the tomato sauce and water. I used diced fire roasted green chilies instead of green peppers and let it simmer and cook down since it was more runny than I wanted. This alone was delicious, then I topped it with enchilada sauce in place of taco sauce. I didn't use chili powder at all since I have littles, so it wasn't real spicy but had a good flavor and just enough kick for the adults to enjoy while being able to "hide" it from a the kids with sour cream and extra cheese.

I have no idea who the people making this recipe are that gave this a 4 star rating but this is a  recipe.  The instructions are horribly written and are actually confusing. The flavor isn't awful but it isn't anything remotely special. It'a just a "Midwest Mom at the last minute/penny pinch" recipe at best. (my sincere apologies to all the wonderful Midwest chefs who actually know how to cook).

This produced an absurd soupy mess and the flavor was about as far from an actual enchilada as one can get. I absolutely highly recommend you just stay away from this mess and find another recipe if you actually have taste buds that are developed and don't like having to fix a poorly constructed recipe on the fly.

When ever I tell my mom I'm making dinner she always requests this. I've made it a number of times and have made a couple of modifications. instead of the the 1/2 of water I usually do somewhere between 1/4-1/3 cup, we do about 1 1/2 cups of cheese for the entire recipe, and I actually cook the green peppers at the same time as the onions. Other than that I don't think I make any other alterations to the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent meal that rivaled the local restaurants. I followed the suggestion of another reviewer and used a 16oz jar of salsa instead of tomato sauce (Newman's Own "Farmer's Garden), omitted the water, used a 7oz can of chopped green chilies instead of green pepper, and subbed a can of Herdez green chili enchilada sauce for the taco sauce. Combined this with the suggestion of boiling the chicken in broth and shredding it when it was "fall apart" done that I read in another review. Definitely worth the extra time and effort. A hearty meal that doesn't break the bank, give it a try.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was awesome !! I read reviews but always make everything my own. I loved this base recipe so much but I did change some things 

*I omitted half the water , because....I used a can of tomato soup + 1/4 cup water instead of tomato sauce (10.5oz can)
*I bought the 19oz red enchilada sauce, so I added 4 oz of it (1/2 cup) to the tomato soup to get the 15oz total that it called for 
* I deboned a rotisserie chicken and chopped that up instead of 4 breast 
* I added 1/2 tsp cumin, and a few chopped jalopanios to the chicken mixture, because they're not as mild as green chilies 
* 2% Mexican cheese blend instead of cheddar 
* red enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce 

These were such easy changes. I half wrote these down to share, half because I wanted to remember extactly what I did so I could make it again for my family !! What a huge hit !!

text:
Turned out great! Changes included using PC Enchiladas dry mix in place of the chilli powder.  I cut my raw chicken into strips, sprinkle/rubbed with tsp. of cumin and poached for 15 minutes in a cup of chicken broth.  Removed chicken, set aside and shredded with two forks.  I cooked 1/3 of the onion, garlic,  1/2 cup chopped yellow/red bell pepper in 1-1/2 tbsp. of olive oil then added 14 oz. tomato sauce.   I made a reduction of the chicken broth adding a tsp. of butter, tsp. of all purpose flour and then stirred in the tomato sauce mixture, chicken and folded in sour cream, onion, cheddar cheese mix.  I topped each roll with a mild corn and black bean salsa, shredded old cheddar and dotted with broken pieces of provolone cheese.

VERY GOOD , TIME CONSUMING, We enjoyed these. I forget what real Mexican enchiladas taste like so I knew we would be fine with this for a change. Time is put into chicken prep. 
The chopping into chunks.  I used tec mex cheese  and a can of green chilies. Watch the chili it was good but don't over do  it. I did not use water, but did use full can of tomato sauce.
I think step 2 1/2 should be added. Prepare meat mixture in  morning . Let the meat and sauce mixture simmer for an hour to let the meat break up a bit more and obsorb the sauce . if you have time  even let it cool . Absolutely no problem or
messy soupyness to put together in afternoon. ILoveIt.

I figured out the most awesome shortcut- Almost homemade! Our local supermarket sells fresh roasted chickens. Let chicken cool down, pull off all meat and you're good to go.

I agree with ditching the water and tomato sauce and replace with two or three cans of red enchilada sauce.

Easy breezy and no mess.
Thanks for the tip on freezing the left over chicken rolls.

text:
This is my first time making chicken enchiladas. I read a few reviews before I made it to get a feel of what to add/omit. I did simmer the chicken breasts in chicken broth to add flavor to the chicken. I omitted the water and used enchilada sauce instead of the taco sauce. Overall my family deemed this recipe a success!  

TIP: The one way I shredded the chicken is to halve the breasts and put in my Kitchen-Aid mixer using the beater  attachment because I was having a heck of a time shredding it with two forks. The chicken came out nicely shredded!

text:
This recipe is REALLY good. Its pretty simple and straightforward and you dont need to do anything different to really have an excellent meal. I've made it probably 5-6 times now and used it after friends have had kids etc. everyone loves it. 

The mixture can be a little watery when you go to fill the tortillas. I like to just use just a little on the bottom of the pan and even dump the extra on the top once they're all filled and in the pan. Use a slotted spoon to fill to make it easier.

text:
The flavor was great -- although I added a tsp of cumin and tripled the garlic. The texture left something to be desired. I found the filling mushy and the tortillas a bit slimy. I think smaller tortillas might go a long way in resolving the sliminess, and maybe reducing the sour cream by a third to reduce the mushiness. The flavor was enjoyable enough that I will probably try this recipe again with those modifications.

Unlike so many others who obviously know their way around the kitchen, I don't. I made no substitutions and I thought this turned out great.  I did omit the water to prevent extra soupiness based on the other reviews.  I recently discovered this website and I'm learning to cook with all the wonderful recipes and tips from other reviewers. I would like to offer a tip for rookies like myself: put A little sauce in the bottom of the pan before adding the enchiladas. This will prevent them from sticking to the bottom of the dish.  If this was in the recipe I missed it.  Thanks for a great dish!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband loved this.  I thought it was a little soggy but it was very tasty.  I boiled the chicken and shredded it.  I wanted to use half the amount of sour cream and replace it with cream cheese but I didn't have any.  Maybe next time.  I used Mexican cheese instead of cheddar.  I used half the amount of tomato sauce and cut out the water all together.  I upped the chili powder to 1 1/2 tablespoons and added 1/2 teaspoon of cumin.  Instead of green pepper I used a can of green chilis, but I think poblano would be great in this.  I used a 10 ounce can of enchilada sauce mixed with 1/4 cup of half and half instead of the taco sauce and I covered the dish with pepper jack cheese and baked for 30 minutes.

text:
These turned out REALLY well. I cooked the chicken in the crock pot on high for 4hrs until it shredded nicely. I added 1/3 cup jalapenos, salt, pepper, and taco seasoning. I did not add any liquid because the chicken breasts were slightly frozen.  I omitted the water entirely, cut the tomato sauce in half and only add 3/4 cup of sour cream. The consistency was perfect and not at all runny.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe, but I did make a few adjustments. Instead of 4 chicken breasts, I cooked an entire bag of chicken (the frozen bags of around 6-8 chicken breasts). I placed the chicken in my pressure cooker with 1/4 cup onion, 1 cup water and 2 tablespoons of salt. Cooked for 20 minutes, then placed the chicken in my stand mixer's bowl. Shredded the chicken then cooked according to directions. Omitted the water. It was not watery at all and was enough to fill about 14 tortillas. I tasted the shredded chicken before adding any ingredients and it was very flavorful. Maybe doing this step beforehand will increase the flavors for those of you saying it didn't have enough.

text:
I am a college student and cooking beginner, and this was a great meal for me to do because it's easy, cheap, stores well (important!) and tastes great. I took the advice on the review as and omitted the water, used half a can of salsa, and enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce. It was watery when I added everything, but it was an easy fix as I just boiled out the liquid for 5-7 mins. I also poached and shredded he chicken, which I think pretty much makes this meal. I also used corn tortillas. So this was delicious but the reason I am giving it 4 starts is because of all these changes that have to be made to make it better.

text:
Made a few modifications because of what I read in reviews and what I had in my pantry.
I doubled the recipe because I was making a meal for a friend and one for my family. 
I only had 5 large chicken  breasts, I cut them up into 2" pieces and cooked. I used tomato sauce but didn't add the water. The mix was really soupy as is. After all ingredients were combined (except I didn't have peppers so omitted them) it was still soupy so I added a can of cream of chicken and it was okay (still a little soupy but not as bad). I also added a can of chicken. I put green enchilada sauce on top instead of taco sauce. Turned out great and my friend said her and her family loved it!

New staple for busy nights with "shift eating" and can be used for quesidillas too!  The liquid allowed me to simmer on low/melt for over an hour. text:
I tend to stay true to original recipes.  My changes were to save time and give the chicken more flavor at the same time.  Working 2 jobs, little time, small budget, and 3 teenagers makes you creative.  I buy 2 whole chickens and make the recipe off here Roast Sticky Chicken-Rotisserie Style on weekend (when there's more time) then use left over chicken for the enchiladas next day.  Easily shaves 30 min. off cook time and is even tastier! I make it along with Mexican Rice II off here and viola!  Once you make both you can get the timing down to 35-40 min supper.  I did go by other suggestions too and used enchilada sauce instead of taco. And I always add extra cheese on top. Hope this helps!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GREAT recipe! My fiance, sister and i reallllllly enjoyed these! This was my first attempted at ever making homemade enchiladas and i nailed it right outta the park! I did make a few changes, but nothing too major. First, I made a dry rub for the chicken of garlic powder, onion powder, oregano & pepper before cooking them. Some people complained of bland flavors so I thought this would help. Also, I'm not a fan of raw onion so after cooking the chicken, i sauteed the onion, green pepper & garlic. Finally, my local store was out of taco sauce so i used mild enchilada sauce. Since this was my first enchilada recipe, i may check out a different one next time to compare, but honestly these were so good i will most likely come back! PS, i did not shred the chicken like others recommended. It turned out just fine :)

text:
This is my absolute favorite recipe to make! It's pretty labor intensive, I've made it about 10 times and it still takes me about 90min to prepare it. I omit the water, only use half the suggested chicken (it's more than enough) and doubled the green peppers. I also cook the onions before I put them in, so that they don't taste so raw. This recipe is a lot of work, but so freakin delicious. It's worth it!

text:
This is the second time I've made this recipe and I follow it exactly how it's written. If you cook off some of the liquid, it's easy to fill the shells and you won't have a "hot, soupy, mess".  I do season the chicken and add extra garlic.  I am going to try other variations with this recipe, but my family and guests were happy with it the way it was.  I do want to try some of the variations that other reviewers have tried.  It's an easy recipe to play around with.  Makes a great, hearty meal for a family of four, with plenty of leftovers!  I'm going to make extra next time and freeze it for later.

country:
None
text:
Despite some of the negative criticism I still decided to try this recipe.  All in all, I think it was pretty good although I did tweak it slightly based on my own preferences.  I seasoned the chicken in the pan with garlic powder. cayenne, cumin, and chili powder and poached it in chicken stock after searing. It was very moist!! I did not add the water as per the recipe. Once adding the tomato sauce etc... I cooked down the liquid until it was my desired thickness.  I made my own taco sauce as I didn't have any on hand.  For my family it still could have been spicier despite it all! Thanks for sharing! :)

text:
This was very good, but using all those liquids would really have made it too soupy. Instead of the water, tomato sauce, and taco sauce, I just used a 19 oz. can of red enchilada sauce, using about 1/3 of the can in with the filling mixture, and the other 2/3 on top of the enchiladas in the baking dish. Husband and son approved; this is definitely being put into the regular dinner rotation at my house.

Based upon other reviewers, I made a few modifications.  Cubed the chicken before saut√©ing in the pan - sprinkled chili powder and pepper on chicken to add flavor. Used 1/4 cup of sour cream and 1/4 cup Greek yogurt along with the cheese and added sliced black olives. Topped with mild chunky salsa (Trader Joe's) and cheese, as others stated the water and tomato sauce made it soupy. It's a little dry - next time I'll try adding enchilada sauce.

text:
Interesting I would say...it DID start out SUPER SOUPY. But, since I have made enchiladas before I know what kind of sauce thickness I like, and when I saw how this was VERY runny before I added the taco/enchilada sauce I skipped it and just added what was in the pan already to the top of the rolled (best I could with it so runny) enchiladas like I usually do otherwise. And then added the cheese. I am guessing that the cooking must have cooked off a good deal of water as it came out a lot closer to what I would expect for "soupiness".

text:
I've been using this recipe to a T since 2008, i love it and anyone who has tried it has also! It always makes more than one 9x13 dish of the enchiladas though which is no complaint on my end but buy extra tortillas! :-) Yesterday I made a portion of them half vegitarian. I didn't add the chicken back tot he skillet, instead I held it aside chopped and added eerything else. I seperate a portion fo it into a bowl and added rinsed black beans to it- enough that made for a good thickness of filling. I then added the chicken tot he skillet. I made a 9x13 dish of the chicken ones and a caserole dish half that size for the vegitarian ones. Both came out fantastic! I highly recommend this recipe and will certainly make the black bean version again too! What a cheap meal that is!

text:
My family loves this recipe and I make it at least once a month.  It is even easier using precooked chicken. I cook a family pack of chicken breasts in the crockpot and then package them into separate meal sized bags to freeze. I just take them out when I need them.  I don't add any water when adding it to the chicken mixture in the skillet and just eyeball the rest of the ingredients.  Also, I use corn tortillas to make these more authentic "enchiladas".  Love this recipe :)

text:
I followed the recipie as far as ingredients were.concerned but I put all ingredients except sour cream, cheese and items from topping in crock pot. I cooked it on high for 8 hours due to the fact that the chicken was frozen. The chicken basically fell apart which saved me all the hassle of shredding the chicken. It was just the right amount of liquid so no sloppy mess! I then added cheese and sour cream and blended it together then followed the directions for stuffing and topping enchiladas! They turned out great and it was a time saver!!!!

userID:
3692918
Display Name:
Cat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
203
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/299205.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
1) I don't use flour tortillas. The texture is too soft as soon as they're out of the oven and the leftovers are so mushy they're almost inedible.  Use yellow corn tortillas. 
2) I think there's no need for the water.  It weakens the flavor and there is plenty of liquid in this recipe without it. Just leave it out.
3) Your hands should be messy by the time you're done making this.  Dip the corn tortilla in the slightly soupy mixture, lay it in the baking dish, spoon in some filling, roll and repeat.  This helps to moisten the corn tortilla a bit and makes the flavor seep into every bite.
The flavor was pretty good.  I'm sure this was nothing like "authentic" enchiladas, but it was tasty enough that my picky husband requested I make it again with corn tortillas.

5

text:
I make these often but I don't really follow the recipe. I make a healthier version. I use whole wheat tortillas, and I don't use sour cream. I cook the chicken as described and add seasoned canned tomatoes instead of tomato sauce. I cover the tortillas in enchilada sauce (I typically buy one can of green, and one can of red), then bake as directed. They come out delicious, and eveyone loves them!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-01-05T04:45:01.96

text:
I couldn't figure out why this recipe would not call for a regular can of enchilada sauce (I usually make my own verde with canned tomatillos) but went against my better judgement and used the jar of Ortega taco sauce. Nothing against the sauce itself, but in the end these enchiladas tasted like strong taco sauce and not much else. I tasted the filling and liked it, so I would recommend using an actual enchilada sauce instead of an entire jar of taco sauce.

text:
SKIP adding the water, you don't need it.  If you cook with a TBSP of oil you don't need the water, it would just make a total mess.

I added black beans and Srircha and it was YUMMY.  I also used Janes Mixed Up Pepper in place of salt and black pepper and I don't measure.  I eyeball it by covering the top with a light layer.  If you are familiar with Janes seasoning, you'll know how much to use :O)  Great recipe for those that LOVE mexican food.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is good.  I had to change it a bit based on what I had in the house.  I used salsa in place of the tomato sauce and water.   I didn't have taco sauce either so I just spooned some of the sauce over the top and covered with cheese.  I eyeballed all of the ingredients, didn't measure anything.  It came out really good. I changed how I put this together a little too.    I put the onion, garlic and spices in with the chicken while it was browning.   Then I added the salsa and the rest of the ingredients.  I let that simmer for a bit and then stuck it in the oven.  I didn't want the chicken to have no flavour. I served with some taco chips for dipping in the sauce and a salad.  Good idea!

It was yummy and plan to make it this weekend...maybe a double batch just in case I have a lazy night!!!!

text:
I very much enjoyed this recipe, although I did following some suggestions to modify it.  I boiled my chicken breasts in stock and then shredded.  Added the herbs/spices, a couple spoons of salsa, diced green chiles and cheese and stirred.  Scooped that mix into the tortillas and got 7 (snacked on the 8th torilla!).  I used a Mexican cheese blend and red enchilada sauce on top.  After baking for 20 min I turned the broiler on to brown the top a bit.  Next time I will add the sour cream and maybe some corn or beans to the filling.  Thanks for the recipe!!

I made refried beans and Spanish rice because I was afraid the enchiladas would bomb. My first such effort.  No one touched the refried beans or the rice because these were so awsome.  Mine were soupy but my family is now convinced that Mexican food has to be soupy to be really good.  Thank you Debbie.  Great verstile and forgiving recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were actually pretty good! I did make a few changes to this recipe including boiling the chicken instead of cooking it in a skillet. I added 2 cans of chicken broth plus another can of water to a pot and boiled the chicken for 5 or so minutes. Then I covered it, let it sit and simmer for about 10 additional minutes. I shredded the chicken instead of dicing them and used that water/both mixture to replace the 1/2 cup of water. I'm also a cheese lover, so I doubled the amount of cheddar cheese. And instead of adding chili powder, I just bought a jar of HOT taco sauce. It was perfect.

text:
This makes a TON of enchiladas so I would cut in half if you don't have a big crowd! They are tasty but I like my mexican food spicy. Used enchiladas sauce in place of the tomato sauce. If you use the sauce you don't have to add chili powder, water and taco sauce. If you make the full amount, you'll be able to fill at least 12-16 flour tortillas, unless you over stuff them. One is more than enough per person especially if you serve with spanish rice as a side.

KILLER!  We strayed a bit - didn't use any tomato sauce or taco sauce...we intended to add enchilada sauce, but forgot to - didn't matter!  This filling is awesome:  creamy and flavorful! Hoping to make this monthly if not bi-weekly - these things ROCK!  (And just like lasagna, are even better next day!!)

country:
None
text:
A really yummy recipe...don't let the number of ingredients deter you!  I made this with a few revisions.  I bought a medium sized rotisserie chicken (they're alreday seasoned!) and deboned it.  I only used an 8oz can of tomato sauce, no water, no oregano, added a can of great northern beans, and used enchilada sauce to coat the bottom of the pan and then poured it over the enchiladas, along with the taco sauce.  My hubby is not a fan of chicken in his Mexican dishes, but he loved this.  They reheat really well and are filling.  Give them a try!!!

text:
Great recipe with some modifications. I used corn tortillas instead of flour. I heated them in a skillet with a small amount of oil to prevent breakage first (standard enchilada procedure). I also used shredded chicken which I poached in water, and added a half a chicken buillon cube---will save the leftover broth for something else. I used fresh parsley (because I had it), added a pinch of cayenne pepper and an extra garlic clove-and instead of the water and tomato sauce I used a can of Rotel (which I would drain next time) and a small amount of salsa. Also used monterrey jack cheese and a packet of enchilada sauce. Yum yum.

text:
THESE WERE AWESOME! I took out the water, made it too supey if I did not. I added 8 oz cream cheeze and 4 oz montery jack cheese. If you add the water by accident, just mix in a 8 oz can of tomato paste and it will fix the problem. I added a half can of tomato paste to my recipe anyways, and IT WAS AWESOME! This is one of my favorite recipes to make! Oh, and after I am done rolling the enchiladas, I add the left over sauce, NOT CHICKEN, to the top of these enchiladas and then brush taco sauce on top of that, of course fallowed with cheese. YUMMY!

text:
Very easy to prepare.  These are good, but the sauce was thin.  Next time I will not add the water.  I scooped the meat mixture out of the pan and used the remaining sauce to pour over the enchiladas.  Did not need to pour the salsa on. Personally I like a lot more heat, so next time I will add some jalapeno juice from jarred jalapenos.  I also substituted 3 fresh, seeded, de-vained, jalapenos for the green pepper.  I topped with some sliced olives, and next time I will also add some scallions to the top.  I think once I 'tweek' this recipe it will suit our taste perfectly.  Thanks for the recipe, Debbie. :-)

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are fantastic and really addictive  I modified the recipe as follows:  Added a jalapeno pepper to chicken recipe as well as some fresh cilantro omitted the water (makes it way to runny) Low fat sour cream I boiled, then shredded the chicken  i sauteed the onion, garlic and peppers, then added the tomato sauce, spices sour cream and cheese.  then added the chicken  I used enchilada sauce instead of the taco sauce and cooked it for about 30 minutes until most of the sauce was absorbed.  Enjoy!!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good basic recipe. BUT if your looking for fast and easy,try buying frozen Burritos or Tiquitos, they are mild in flavor, but it cuts down on the cooking time. Also use red enchilada sauce (small can)and large can of tomato sauce. Mix together and pour 1/3 into bottom of pan,prevents burning. Add burritos and cook uncovered 10 min. add the rest of sauce and 2 cups favorite cheese,Tex-Mex , Cheddar or Colby mix. Be sure the sauce covers everything and cook 10-15 min. more, or cheese is melted. If you like the beans add before sauce or heat and serve as a side.

text:
This is a delicious recipe.  I usually try to review a recipe "as is," but I did do 2 things different.  I prefer my chicken shredded, so I either boil it or cook it in the Crock Pot overnight, then shred it.  The other difference is that instead of the jarred taco sauce, I made red enchilada sauce from another recipe on this site.  They are delicious.  I may make it with jarred taco sauce in the future if I have less time.  I usually make a double batch and freeze half to have another ready-made meal for a busy night.  Great recipe!

text:
In the interest of saving time and because I had it on hand I used two cans of Kirkland premium chunk chicken breast.  I also substituted red enchilada sauce in place of taco sauce. And although the flavor was good it was too watery so next time I will omit the water. The tortillas stuck to the pan so I will also coat the bottom with sauce or use cooking spray.  It was an easy (I guess because I used canned chicken!) and tasty meal.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy! I changed a few things and it was so good, will make again.  I only made half the recipe and made these changes: used 3T tomato sauce, 2T sour cream, 2 chicken breasts, 1 jalepeno (seeds and all), 1/3 of a green pepper chopped, small onion chopped, 1/4 tsp oregano, 1 tsp parsley, 3/4 cup cheddar cheese, 1 garlic clove, 1 dash of chili powder, salt and pepper.  I used canned enchilada sauce over the rolled up tortillas (just enough to cover the tortillas) and then I topped it with more cheese.  The jalepeno was just the right amount of spice, I wish half the recipe made more than 4 enchiladas.  If you like it spicy, this is the way to do it!  Will definitely make this again!!!!

text:
I use a simplier recipe.  boil 2 chicken breasts, and shread once cooked.  Using one corn tortilla per enchilada, pan fry the tortilla (just very little) then dip into store bought enchilada sauce to cover.  Place on plate and add shredded chicken, shredded cheese (your preference, I use Colby Jack) and olives.  I then fold like a burrito and add more sauce on top with a little shredded cheese and a dab of sour cream.  Easy and fast.

This was a great base recipe.  After reading tons of reviews, I left out the tomato sauce and water altogether and substituted green chiles for the green pepper.  This made for a creamy filling, rather than tomato-y.  
Like another reviewer, I made these ahead, minus the enchilada sauce & cheese on top.  Pulled it out of the fridge later, threw the necessities on top, baked for 30 minutes.  It was delicious.  Will be my standard.

text:
Great and easy!  I let the chicken filling cool some before filling the tortillas. Also, I used thigh meat instead of breast so it had a much stronger chicken flavor.  Instead of sauce and water in the filling, using canned enchilada sauce works fine and adds a little more flavor, too. Finally, I didn't smother the top with sauce but covered lightly which made it a lot easier to remove from the pan once baked.  This is a very good base recipe which is quick to make.  I make the filling while the kids are at school then put it together 30 minutes before dinner time.

Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2008-07-18T21:56:04.247
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
1032812
Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:
False
followersCount:
97
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1009
favoritesCount:
2526
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just don't see what all the rage is about these.  I don't find this recipe to be worthy of 5 stars at all.  Made these as the main dish for a Cinco de Mayo dinner that I prepared for my friend and I. After hearing from another friend who tried/recommended these, and, because of her 5 star rating, I thought we'd be in for a real treat. I read EVERY review here and incorporated some of the suggestions given. Even then, I wasn't impressed. Here's what I did: a) purchased a rotisserie chicken, deboned it and shredded the white meat for the enchiladas, b) omitted the green pepper alltogether (didn't seem right to add it to an enchilada), c) subbed a 4 oz. can of diced green chilies (drained) for the bell pepper, and d) used a can of authentic enchilada sauce in place of the taco sauce called for. Despite the addition of hot green chilies, medium-heat enchilada sauce and all of the chili powder, my enchiladas seemed bland and tasted more like sour cream than anything else.  It could have been that my chili powder lost it's potency (I've had it for a while), but I doubt it.....  It just seems as if there should be more heat given the ingredient list (and the chili powder measurement). These were OK warm out of the oven, but not good re-heated.  Not bad, but definitely not great either.  My friend seemed to like these (hence a 3 star rating), but I think she would agree that I've made better. Sorry, this recipe didn't work for me at all.
Review:
Rating:
5

Very good! I too made a few changes: 

Substituted enchilada sauce for taco sauce, and mexican/taco cheese mix instead of just cheddar. I left out the tomato sauce and water.

text:
This recipe is so good.  I did change it a little bit at the request of my husband and to suit our tastes...
Boil the chicken in broth & then shred (I do this ahead of time in bulk to save time)...
Diced tomatoes instead of tomato sauce.
No Chili Powder
Use red and/or orange bell peppers instead of green.
Use canned MILD enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce.
AND...  we add frozen corn to the mix, which adds so much to the flavor & makes it healthier...

country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe. Everyone in my house loves these. I cut the chicken up first and then cooked it, and saut√© the vegetables as suggested by other reviewers. I also omit the water. Other than that, I make the recipe as is. I make enough for leftovers and that doesn't stay around at all.  *Update* - instead of cooking the chicken in the frying pan, I've been boiling it in chicken broth. Let it cool a bit, then cut it up into chunks. The chicken tends to shred this way, making for a nice texture to the enchiladas. I saut√© the onions, garlic and peppers in butter, add the cooked chicken, then follow the recipe with the remaining ingredients, omitting the water.  Sometimes I add wine to the pan if the sauce needs a little more moisture, which depends on the size of the chicken breasts/parts I'm using.

text:
The first time I made these they were great and were perfect, the second time I made them they were not as good as the first time. The problem: I bought generic sour cream and it separated when I added it in. So my advice is that by the name brand kinds. The flavor wasn't that different and I actually served it to my guests and everybody said it was good, but I felt kinda OCD about it! I also garnished the layer of cheese on top with fresh parsley. I served it with guacamole and Spanish rice the first time, and guacamole and a salad with balsamic vinegar (you don't need anything to creamy).Also once it is done, you can garnish the enchilada with some red onions, black beans and corn..it looks super pretty! This is a dish that really pleases most palettes, highly recommended!

text:
These enchiladas had a lot of flavor. I added a little more kick to the filling by adding 1/2 teaspoon of pepper flakes. The filling was a bit runny so I had to fold in the corners of the tortilla to keep the filling in. 

Also, I boiled the chicken to scoop out the fat easier and then I cubed the chicken and tossed them in the skillet. Additionally, I added the garlic, onion, and bell peppers in the skillet before adding the chicken. From there, I followed the rest of the recipe.

country:
None
text:
1) Purchased baked chicken breasts (4 pieces) from the deli counter at my grocery store and shredded them.  2) Used salsa INSTEAD of tomato sauce. 3) OMITTED water. 4) Used a 4 oz can of green chilies INSTEAD of green bell pepper. 5) Used 'Red Enchilada Sauce' (a recipe submitted by Sara and found on this site) INSTEAD of jarred taco sauce.  The entire meat mixture can be made up ahead of time, refrigerated overnight and reheated before assembling into the tortillas and baking.  I used parchment to line the pan and they came up without sticking, and cleanup was a snap.

userID:

Display Name:
GochisosamaDeshita
isPro:

20

madeRecipesCount:
67
favoritesCount:
206
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5832066.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified this recipe  a bit to make it even faster and tastier...  I heated a package of frozen, southwest-seasoned chicken breast strips in the microwave per package instructions.  Then coarsely chop and place in microwave-safe mixing bowl with 1 C  shredded mexican cheese blend and 8 oz sour cream.  Heat for 3 minutes, then stir in 1 (4 oz) can  mild green chiles, 1 (10 oz) can Rotel, 1 (8 oz) can tomato sauce, a dash of chili powder and a dash of garlic powder.  I spooned this mixture into small flour tortillas, rolled them up, placed them in a 9x13 baking dish, and poured a can of enchilada sauce over the top.  Baked at 350 F for 20 minutes and served with spanish rice and refried beans.  Yummy and quick!

text:
This is by far the best enchilada recipe that I have tried! The only thing I did different was I only used 8 oz's of the tomato sauce, about 1/3 C. of water (could have used less), grated about 1/4 C. of onion (otherwise my kids wouldn't eat it if they saw it), & I had to omit the green pepper (for the same reason). Every one loved it in my family-- even my picky 10 year old gave it a thumbs-up. A very tasty recipe!!! Thanks for sharing.

text:
I omitted the water, and still had a soupy filling, so I added some frozen, cooked turkey to the sauce.  I poached and shredded my chicken then sauted the onions and added the chicken to it.  I also added some frozen chopped anahiem peppers in place of the bell pepper.  Because I am not very fond of taco sauce, I took reviewers suggestions and made Red Enchilada Sauce (which is fantastic). Although these enchiladas were not particularly bad, they were not very good.  I thought they were a rather bland.  My husband loved them, as did the kids; and I will make them again but only for thier sake.

text:
This was my first time making Enchiladas, and it was so good I almost couldn't believe I made it!!  I used already cooked turkey meat instead of chicken (wanted to use some thanksgiving leftovers that were in the freezer) and it was wonderful.  I omited the salt because I also made the Red Enchilada Sauce from this site, and I accidently made it a little  too saltly. This really was a great dinner. I plan to make it many more times in the future.  **Only changes I made was of course the turkey and instead of a whole onion(we aren't big onion people) I used a few shakes of some dried minced onion. I also thought the spices were perfect!  Not bland at all as others have said.

This was the first time I have ate or made an enchilada. I think it turned out pretty good. When I was getting ready to add the sourcream, I saw that it had expired. text:
Great recipe. I used Trader Joe's Hot and Spicy Chipotle picante sauce instead of taco sauce. It gave the recipe a wonderful smokey, rich flavor. Instead of pouring on top, I poured the sauce in the chicken mixture, let it cook down a little and then stuffed the tortillas. I didn't bake until the next day. Also, upped the amount of cheddar cheese. Served with sour cream to cut the heat a bit. It was a great way to use up some leftover Sam's Club roasted chicken. If I didn't use the chipotle salsa, I don't think the recipe would have been as good.
