city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading some reviews, I tweaked the recipe to these specs., it turned out sooooo delicious. Here's what I did: Add an extra ounce or two of sour cream. Sub 16 0z. mild Best Choice picante sauce for tomato sauce.
Add one can green chiles. Add one can Rotel, drained. Omitted green bell pepper. Cook onions with initial chicken cooking. Add extra garlic.
Use 1 1/2 cup cheese in "sauce". Use 16 oz. medium Best Choice taco sauce.
Dip flour tortillas in sauce before filling/rolling. Use 1 1/2 cup cheese on top. Omit water. (In my local grocery store [in Northwest Arkansas], the variety of salsas/picantes is slim. I've found that the best tasting out of the major name brands are the "Best Choice" products. -- Who'd a thought??) Delicious!!!!! Thanks for a fabulous recipe.

text:
Excellent recipe, even better left over.  Here are a few suggestions ~ Shred your chicken instead of dicing.  My veggies were too crunchy so next time I will add the onion/bell pepper at same time & cook for a minute or two before adding the cheese.  I omitted only the taco sauce and instead made the "Red Enchilada Sauce" on this site (as some previous reviewers suggested)- AWESOME touch to the enchiladas!!!  This enchilada recipe is a mild one, so for some added spice in your filling you may want to add some cayenne or crushed red pepper and maybe top the enchiladas with a jalepeno slices.

text:
Excellent recipe. After reading the other reviews I did the following: season my chicken prior to cooking it, omitted the water and the tomatoe sauce and used enchilada sauce in it's place (10 oz), I also used enchilada sauce to pour on top instead of the taco sauce.  I reduced the amount of chili powder for my 18 month daughter, it had a little kick but was not too spicey. Next time I would leave out the green peppers and possibly add refried or black beans. I used whole wheat tortillas and didnt taste a differnce between whole wheat and flour and the wheat is much healthier. Thanks Debbie!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good!  The only thing I omitted was the salt.  Next time I'm going to leave out the water and use canned chicken breast (Hormel makes a wonderful one)- I found cooking and cubing the chicken to be a pain in the neck.  Can't wait to make again!

**Update:  I make these ALL the time now, with my own little touches:  use 1 10 oz can Hormel chicken breast (drained) and mix with the onions, sour cream, etc.  Omit the water- this makes the filling too runny. I use wheat tortillas instead of the regular white ones- better for you and a little thicker so they hold the filling better.  I also use Ortega (mild) taco sauce- the best, in my opinion.  This recipe makes 2 great dinners- I use half the filling and freeze the other half for another meal.  We are HOOKED on these-  thanks so much!!!

text:
Great recipe!  I have made it three times for guests and it was always a hit.  Instead of chopping up boneless chicken breast halves, I boiled chicken on the bone and then deboned it.  That way, I had shredded chicken in the enchildadas instead, which is always better than diced chicken in my opinion.  Plus, then you have broth for soup later.

I make these a lot, they are the best enchiladas I have ever had! However, there are two changes that you have to make for these: omit the 1/2 cup water, it is not needed and will make them too soupy. Also, use enchilada sauce NOT taco sauce. You will love them if you love spicy food!

This was a big hit, even for my ever-picky stepdaughters!  Some changes I made:  They aren't chicken lovers, so I used 1 1/2 lb. ground beef instead. I also omitted the green peppers (for my husband's sake), and I had to simmer for quite a while to reduce it.  I wasn't crazy about the taco sauce on it - too tangy and not the best complement to the flavor of the filling.  I'm going to experiment with some of the other suggestions here and see if I can't perfect it.  But aside from that, this was simply outstanding!!!

This recipe is definitely a keeper!  YUMMMM!

country:
None
text:
The filling was awesome but next time will use enchilade sauce (homemade) as I felt the taco sauce didn't do the filling justice.  I did the recipe for 4 servings.  I used 8" corn tortillas (perfect size).  I microwaved them for 30 secs and they rolled easily, no problem.  I boiled and shredded the chicken (3 breasts - made enough to fill 10 tortillas!).  Used FF cheddar cheese and LF sour cream which was good.  Also used a 10 oz can of Rotel instead of the tomato sauce and eliminated the water.  Next time will try adding a little tomato paste as well as it was a tiny bit dry.  Spice level was perfect (I like spicy food, but it was not too hot).

Yummy!  I did change a bit.  I doubled the garlic and added another ck breast.  I did not have sour cream, instead I use half a tub of onion and chive cream cheese and substituted tomato sauce with paste and added water to thin out.  I don't like bell pepper, so I added a raw jalapeno (removed seeds) and added cumin.  Instead of flour tortillas, I used corn tortillas softened in a little hot oil so that they would not crumble.  Tastes even better the next day.  Used pace enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce.

This was delish! I didn't put in green peppers and used just a little dried onion instead of real. To "shred" my chicken I used my Pampered Chef food chopper and that worked slick! I also probably added extra tomato & taco sauce and a little more cheese (we live in Wisconsin, it's all about the cheese). I used a Mexican cheese mix from Sargento. It all turned out delicious and pretty easy to make, I'm sure it will become one of our staple meals! Next time I think I'll add one more chicken breast to "beef" up the meat. I can't wait for my leftovers at lunch today!

Mexican dinner night used to be tacos or fajitas from a box, but these are infinitely better! I made a few alterations.  I seasoned and baked the chicken breasts for 1 hour at 325 F, then shredded them the next day.  I sauted the onion, green pepper and the garlic, added the spices, then added the shredded chicken to heat it through.  I put all that in a bowl, added the other ingredients and wrapped them in CREPES!  I borrowed my friends crepe maker and have been playing around with it, so I thought why not?  They were delicious!

text:
Delicious!  I made a few modifications out of necessity (fat-free sourcream and low fat cheddar, can of Campbell's tomato soup instead of tomato sauce, salsa instead of taco or enchilada sauce) and also added yellow and red peppers because I had them on hand.  I didn't add the water.  I found the filling a little runny while hot, so I let it cool a bit before rolling into the tortillas.  My husband and I loved it and will definitely add this to the regular supper rotation.  Thank you Debbie for the delicious recipe!

text:
Made these but unfortunately did not read the reviews first.  Do not add the 1/2 cup water.  That makes the whole thing too runny and made it hard to roll the enchiladas without everything pouring out.    I suggest using smaller than 10" tortillas.  I couldn't fit 8 in a 9"x13" pan because they wouldn't fit sideways.  I think an 8" tortilla would be perfect.  I made the Enchilada Sauce also found on this website instead of taco sauce and that turned out good but made the entire thing too much for me.  I probably won't make these again, but only because it was too much effort.

text:
I made this for my Super Bowl dinner party.  Everyone loved them.  Even good leftover the next day.  I did add one large fresh tomatoe, along with 1/2 jar of Mexican style tomatoes, used extra garlic, a small can of green chilis, and did not use any water.  I also boiled my chicken with onions and celery flakes instead of in the frying pan as the receipe suggests.  I used 1/2 enchilada sauce and 1/2 taco sauce for top and I used extra cheese inside and on the top.  They turned out great!! I suggest making them with the fat free refried beans because they are also great!!

text:
My husband and I really liked this recipe.  As suggested by other reviewers, I excluded the water and added some cumin.  The cumin really gives it the 'mexican' flavor.  Also, if you decide to add hot sauce for a 'kick', be carefull which kind you use.  I used some sauce we picked up in Jamaica and it totally changed the flavor:(.

text:
To make these even faster, while you're making the sauce, bbq/grill the chicken and then mix the chopped hot chicken with the sauce and cheese, fill warmed tortillas and spoon a little sauce over each serving and top with cheese. I omited the baking, it just takes too long when everyone is hungry. To make the recipe lower in fat I omitted the butter and used 1/2 fat soup and lowfat sourcream.
